bboxes.raw_text:
Arizona motor vehicle regis
trations increased SO percent
in 1868 with a total of 855.775
vehicles registered at year end.
Passenger cars accounted for
583,843. followed by commercial
vehicles with ll3,74l. and trail
ers Qncluding house) with 81 PIG.
Non-commercial trucks plus
buses, taxis, motorcycles and
scooters accounted for the bal
ance.


Between 1882 and 1862, Ari-
IONA posted III percent gain
in passenger car registrations
AMI showed the greatest rate Of
growth in registrations Of any
western state.

What is there in the air now7
Californians are going to the polls
to cast ballots for free televi-
sion or pay television.


Perhaps with the summer re-
runs waiting In the wings, we
should have another vote to de-
eide wether to accept the tele
vision programs or reject them.


Television has brought some
interesting programs to us. 1t
has provided us with some spec
tacular events in the sports world
and in the theater. 1t has given
us many thrills and laughs and
1t has brought Joy and tragedy,
too.


Too many excellent shows have
been cancelled because Of GER
tain ratings. Too many mediocre
ones stay on year after year.
evidently the low budget shows
manage to keep on for obvious
reasons.


Several programs nominated
for Emmy Awards will not be
seen next season. The joke was
to be nominated the show had
TO have been axed recently.


We enjoy many programs and
look forward to some of the rare
plays or operas which do appear
now and then.


Looking over the schedule
would have one believe that all
of us want to see comical ami
mails, puppets and other chill
dren shows.


Sing Along With Mitch keeps
its humming formal every week
while Andy Williams never lets
us forget his old Iowa home.


There Is one thing about the
friendly Martian--he manages to
outsmart these Earthlings. No
doubt he watched our television
shows before landing.


Western actors have been COW
cred with two guns, rifle barrels,
paisley printed vests, sequined
breeches and hip boots--but they
still went that away.


Western stories are not set In
old Kansas saloons or a small
and poor ranch. Todayin the tele-
vision producers book the
settings must be plush saloons
and huge ranch spreads under the
ponderosa pines.


| used to vince as Roy Rogers
and Gene Autry made their way
over the dusty trail. They would
be a welcome relief now to the
glib talking cowboys who roam
the television range.


Gone are the days Of Sam Spade,
Mr.. and Mrs. North, the Thin
Man or the Saint. How | would
like to see just one of the old
school the knock down rough
and ready private eye operate
again.


Before we worry about voting
for pay or free television--lets
lombard the sponsors and pro-
ducers to increase the number
and type of shows.


would like to give Emmys
of the year for the worst local
TV personalities to Aquanetta
and Wallace.


These two should make team
and take their show to New York
l am sure they could catch
sponsor. After all they have little
talent.

If you've exhausted stamp
swapping possibilities in your
town, start Il "pen pal" swap
with collectors in other cities or
even foreign countries. Send lists
Of stamps you'll swap and those

you want. Stamp clubs can put
you in touch with individuals in
this country. Schools, libraries,
the Red Cross may have names of
pen pals abroad.

AEZ6N1 NEWSPAPERS ASSOCIATION AMALcAMATEo PUBLISHERS


NO One SPEAKS FOR ALL


Two Negro civil rights leaders appeared ON
nationally teleUiSed programs Sunday and
Uoiced their UieWS. They represent tVo groups
which haze sbeaYheaded demonstrations Which
haze brought attention and results.


Dr.. Martin L. King, Jy., head Of the South
eYn Christian Leadership Conference, gave
several opinions on the problems ia cling the
country because Of failure Of the ciUil rights
measure in Congress. He seemed disturbed
because the bin hadn't made more progress
and he mas surprised When advocates Of the
bin UeYe nOlO possibly making concessions
to Wotey the bin down.


Dr.. King again refused TO accept j. Edgar
HOOUeY'S statements that Communists abound
in the Negroes ciUil rights organizations. He
YetOYted that WaS amazing that such fen
Negroes had ever fallen under the influence Of
communism in spite Of the conditions in this
country.


The second spotlight Of the day occurred
dxYi,g the interview of James Farmer, ma
tional dire ctoY of the Congress Of Ra cial
Equality.


Mn. Farmers group initiated freedom
rides and it has been very active in U0teY
registrations drives.


He felt the churches had been too SlO1O in
making any moves to end segregation within
their ranks.


Mn. Farmer favored Transporting pupils out
Of their home area districts to alleviate racial
school segregation caused by boundary lines.


His vieWs on the Ills Of the Negro race laid
blame on Negroes Initiating aO1iteS. He could
locate no other point.


Both men agreed that an increased type Of
demonstration would take place if the ciUil
rights measure 1VaS not passed. Both pre-
dicted greater summer activities.


Dr.. King and Mn. Farmer may lead their
Yesbe ctiUe groups, but W1en they SPEAK they
can not speak for Is million Negroes. AS ne
reach for equal opportunities and rights, ne
can not lose our indiUiduahty and be come
mere herd Of sheep.

Agiz6HA NEWSPAPERS ASSOCIATION
. Fes Greater pvblIe Ssvvies

vi SIHVVI SUUIeIIS


On the southSide of Phoenix a man has ab-
pointed himself byotec toY Of the realm. He
must imagine he is a modern day knight Wh0
must go into the field Of combat against the
dragons. The dragons which ReU. Aubrey
Moore encounters are not monsters WlO luTR
in the woods.


Req. Moore and his followers we're able to
arouse public action and halt the housing code
in Phoenix. This code is needed to eliminate
many health and safety hazaydS and permit re-
building Of 6hghted neighboyhoodS.


To-Day Mn. Moore IS Waging another battle.
He denounces the teaching Of the theory Of
evolution in our schools. Mn. Moore believes
in The Bible. He said all others who adhere to
any theories such as evolution are atheists.


He and his followers represent segment
of the population 1Oho refuse to keep in step
with the modern World. They are quick to refer
to their religion in all arguments.


The great issue is not the tea ching of eU0M-
tiOn or any other scientific theory. The issue
is hidden and often hidden buYb0Sely, because
the American tradition is on trial.


The tradition Of freedom to teach and Free
dom to learn is being threatened when men
like Aubrey Moore would haze the curriculum
of our schools become issues at the polls.


Seeds Of a t0ta litaYs0n society are SCUM IN
small rows. Those aOho WiSh to dictate what
shah be taught in the schools wiA go to any
lengths to min approval

Views, pREvIews
ANo REVIEWS


Edward Banks

Beware Of Curbs


On School Subjects
